MCS RMP Executive Summary

1.0          Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source

Mid-America Conversion Services, LLC (MCS) is committed to conducting work in a manner that protects workers, the public, and the environment. This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in safety throughout facility design, construction, operation and maintenance. MCS has developed detailed programs and procedures to effectively implement this commitment. The programs and procedures systematically integrate safety, health, environmental protection and quality assurance into all levels of management and work practices. 

2.0          Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

MCS operates a Depleted Uranium Hexafluoride (DUF6) Conversion Facility for the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) at Kevil, Kentucky to disposition DUF6 into a safer, more manageable product. The facility employs a dry conversion process that converts DUF6 to uranium oxide powder that is collected and packaged for reuse or disposal. The process also utilizes steam and hydrogen as reaction gases, which produce hydrofluoric acid (HF) as a saleable end product.  

The maximum HF acid concentration produced is approximately 55 wt% HF acid solution, per the MCS Safety Data Sheet (SDS).  However, the typical concentration is less than 50%.  A total maximum quantity of 460,000 pounds of HF acid is temporarily stored on-site in several tanks before transfer to tanker trucks or rail cars for offsite shipment. This amount exceeds the threshold quantity specified in 40 CFR 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.  Further evaluation indicates that the Conversion Facility is subject to Program 1 requirements of 40 CFR 68. HF acid is the only chemical associated with the DUF6 Conversion Facility that exceeds the threshold quantities specified in 40 CFR 68.

3.0          General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Preven

tion Steps

MCS has addressed identification and evaluation of potential accidents and associated prevention and mitigation features in Documented Safety Analyses (DSA) documents prepared for and approved by the DOE. MCS has implemented the required controls through an extensive set of programs and procedures. These programs and procedures also apply to the management of structures, systems, components and programs that pertain to Risk Management Plan (RMP) covered process and related activities.

As part of the DSAs, process safety analyses have been conducted to identify potential hazards in the process and associated controls to prevent and mitigate releases. These controls include passive barriers, active features, and operator actions.

The primary controls associated with the storage of HF acid are the HF storage tanks. These tanks are designed to contain the HF acid under conditions such as credible natural phenomena events. A dike around each tank provides secondary containment for potential tank leaks. HF vapor detectors and tank level sensors provide indications should a leak occur, and automatically actuate valves to isolate the HF storage tanks. Operators are required to monitor transfers from the HF storage tanks to the rail cars or tanker trucks and manually stop the transfer should a leak occur. Installed pumps and piping can be used to pump any leaked material back into the HF storage tanks for sampling and reprocessing.

In addition to the aforementioned controls, MCS also has programs to ensure safe and effective operations. These programs include but are not limited to the following: Radioactive and Hazardous Waste Management; Industrial Safety, Initial Testing, In-Service Surveillance and Maintenance; Fire Protection; Procedures and Training; Emergency Management; Configuration Management; Conduct of Operations; Unreviewed Safety Question; and Quality Assurance.

Operating and maintenance procedures have been established and operators h

ave been trained on routine evolutions as well as process startup, shutdown, maintenance and emergency operations. All work is performed in accordance with pre-approved written procedures or work packages.

4.0          The Five Year Accident History

There have been no offsite or reportable quantity releases of HF acid at the facility.

5.0          The Emergency Response Program 

MCS has developed a written emergency plan to provide a comprehensive description of emergency preparedness and response to operational emergencies at the DUF6 Conversion Facility. The plan flows down the applicable requirements of the Deactivation and Remediation (D&R) Contractor (currently Four Rivers Nuclear Partnership, LLC [FRNP]) Emergency Plan and describes the DUF6 Paducah Project emergency management program.  The D&R Contractor is the lead organization responsible for managing the overall direction and control of emergency responses at the Paducah site. MCS is responsible for overall compliance of the program with applicable regulations and implementation of the D&R Contractor plan, while ensuring DOE requirements are met. 

This program has been established to manage and respond to accidents or other emergency situations in a consistent and integrated way. The structure of this program is intended to ensure that the consequences of emergencies are promptly mitigated and that the health and safety of the public, personnel on the surrounding DOE reservation, plant personnel, and environment are protected, regardless of the cause or nature of the emergency. The D&R Contractor Emergency Management organization is responsible for maintaining and updating the Emergency Plan as appropriate.

The Emergency Plan describes the emergency response structure and the roles and responsibilities prior to, during and after an emergency. The plan describes the actions during an emergency which include the following: declaration of an emergency, activation of the Emergency Operation

Center (EOC), emergency response, reentry, and event termination. Upon notification of an event, the field Emergency Response Organization (ERO) is activated for response to the scene and mitigation of the incident.  Emergencies are classified through a site-wide standardized system that uses Emergency Action Levels (EALs) as criteria for equating an incident to a specific emergency classification level. Using the specific criteria outlined in the EALs, the D&R Contractor Plant Shift Superintendent (PSS) determines the level of response and protective actions required and determines if the event meets the proper criteria to classify the event as an Alert or a Site Area Emergency (SAE). Upon determination of event classification, the Incident Commander (IC) makes notifications to off-site agencies and activates the EOC Cadre. 

Emergency response facilities have been pre-designated and equipped for use in an emergency. The Central Control Facility is continuously staffed, performing "routine" response-related activities, such as handling requests for ambulances or dispatching protective force personnel. Dedicated facilities, such as the EOC, are immediately available to support emergency operations upon arrival of staff. 

Prompt notification of on-site personnel, emergency responders, and off-site organizations and agencies is critical during an emergency event. The D&R Contractor PSS is responsible for notifying the ERO using the plant radio system, pagers, Public Address (PA) system and/or the plant telephone system.

The severity of some emergencies on-site may warrant the use of off-site response personnel, organizations, and agencies. As a result, agreements with off-site support agencies have been developed and are maintained by the D&R Contractor. Off-site support services may include medical assistance, fire control, evacuation, law enforcement, and ambulance services. 

During emergencies, the D&R Contractor PSS (or designee) or the Crisis Manager (

CM) must determine the best initial protective actions to limit exposure of on-site and off-site personnel to potential or actual threats. EALs detailing protective action criteria have been developed for the protection of on-site and off-site personnel. Protective actions for on-site personnel include alerting, assembly/accountability, sheltering-in-place, evacuation, monitoring, and decontamination.

The D&R Contractor maintains medical coverage consistent with the activities being conducted on-site. In an emergency, off-duty medical personnel are notified and directed to required locations, if needed.

The D&R Contractor maintains and updates the Emergency Public Information (EPI) Plan and maintains the Continuity of Operations Plan, to which MCS provides information. The purpose of the EPI Plan is to establish a basis for providing timely, accurate, and relevant information to personnel and the public who may be affected by an emergency at the site.

When corrective and protective actions have established an effective control over the situation, and emergency conditions no longer exist, the emergency response shifts into the recovery phase. It is the responsibility of the D&R Contractor CM to determine when the recovery phase of the emergency can be initiated.

The D&R Contractor is responsible for administering the Emergency Management training program for EOC cadre personnel and Joint Information Center (JIC) personnel. Course modules have been developed to ensure personnel functioning in these roles receive adequate training. All MCS personnel who are involved in emergency planning possess experience or a combination of experience, training, and education commensurate to their job assignment. Management for each individual's training plan for continuing professional development identifies any additional technical course requirements.

The D&R Contractor manages the Emergency Management Drill and Exercise (D&E) Program at the Paducah site. Drills and

exercises are conducted to develop, maintain, and test the response capabilities of emergency personnel, facilities, equipment, procedures, and training. 

MCS' EM Specialist manages the Emergency Management Program for DUF6.  MCS performs limited scope drills for the MCS managed areas/buildings. The D&E Committee plans and conducts annual site-wide emergency exercises. The exercise tests the integrated capability of all or most of the basic elements existing within the emergency plan and procedures. Exercises utilize scenarios that are wider in scope than drills and may involve off-site response personnel and agencies. 

The D&R Contractor Emergency Management group is responsible for maintaining and updating the site Emergency Plan as appropriate. The MCS Emergency Management Specialist is responsible for maintaining the MCS Emergency Plan and program. 

6.0          Planned Changes to Improve Safety       

MCS utilizes a variety of feedback and continuous improvement methods on an ongoing basis to evaluate the adequacy and effectiveness of the Conversion Facility programs, processes and procedures to ensure continuous improvement. Data is collected at the program and task levels.

MCS management systems for feedback and continuous improvement include assessments, subcontract submittals and reporting protocols. These management systems provide ongoing evaluation of both MCS and subcontractor performance to ensure conformance to specified requirements and effective implementation. Examples of these systems include self-assessments and independent assessments to provide ongoing, formal feedback. Issues identified from assessments are documented, causal analyses are performed, and corrective actions developed and tracked to closure. Analyses are conducted on a regular basis to identify trends for management action. Data from these processes are evaluated by senior management to identify opportunities for improvement.
